channel.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
channel.description:
Well I have been trying to convert a string such as "42fha6sd4" into an int 4264 to ignore everything except numbers and save it as an int. Is there any way to do this?
The reason why I need this is because I'm trying to use the showInputDialog in JOptionPane and when you enter information into showInputDialog it returns it as a string. But I need the user to pick a number and compare that number to different number to see if it is less than, greater than, or equal to it.
By the way, this is a guessing game. The computer randomly picks a number between 1 and 100 and stores it in an int "answer" and in a String named "answerString." Here is the method I'm using at the moment:
[code] private void guess() {
String guessString = JOptionPane.showInputDialog(frame, "Guess a number" + " between 1 and 100", "Guess A Number", 3);
if(guessString != null && !(guessString.equals(""))) { int guess = Integer.parseInt(guessString); // this is where the error happens I think if(guessString.equals(answerString)) { JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(frame, "You got it right!", "You Win!", 1); } else if(guess < answer) { JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(frame, "Too low. Try again.", "Too Low", 1); } else if(guess > answer) { JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(frame, "Too high. Try again.", "Too High", 1); } } } [/code]
If they were to enter letters (such as f) in it, it gives this big error:
[code] Exception in thread "AWT-EventQueue-0" java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "f" at java.lang.NumberFormatException.forInputString(NumberFormatException.java:48) at java.lang.Integer.parseInt(Integer.java:447) at java.lang.Integer.parseInt(Integer.java:497) at Game.guess(Game.java:153) at Game.actionPerformed(Game.java:46) at javax.swing.AbstractButton.fireActionPerformed(AbstractButton.java:1995) at javax.swing.AbstractButton$Handler.actionPerformed(AbstractButton.java:2318) at javax.swing.DefaultButtonModel.fireActionPerformed(DefaultButtonModel.java:387) at javax.swing.DefaultButtonModel.setPressed(DefaultButtonModel.java:242) at javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicButtonListener.mouseReleased(BasicButtonListener.java:236) at java.awt.Component.processMouseEvent(Component.java:6216) at javax.swing.JComponent.processMouseEvent(JComponent.java:3265) at java.awt.Component.processEvent(Component.java:5981) at java.awt.Container.processEvent(Container.java:2041) at java.awt.Component.dispatchEventImpl(Component.java:4583) at java.awt.Container.dispatchEventImpl(Container.java:2099) at java.awt.Component.dispatchEvent(Component.java:4413) at java.awt.LightweightDispatcher.retargetMouseEvent(Container.java:4556) at java.awt.LightweightDispatcher.processMouseEvent(Container.java:4220) at java.awt.LightweightDispatcher.dispatchEvent(Container.java:4150) at java.awt.Container.dispatchEventImpl(Container.java:2085) at java.awt.Window.dispatchEventImpl(Window.java:2475) at java.awt.Component.dispatchEvent(Component.java:4413) at java.awt.EventQueue.dispatchEvent(EventQueue.java:599) at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpOneEventForFilters(EventDispatchThread.java:269) at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEventsForFilter(EventDispatchThread.java:184) at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEventsForHierarchy(EventDispatchThread.java:174) at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEvents(EventDispatchThread.java:169) at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEvents(EventDispatchThread.java:161) at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.run(EventDispatchThread.java:122) [/code]
So to summarize, I want to turn String "5dff4uaise3" and others like it into int 543. I want to only keep numbers the user has inputted.
Thanks in advance, FireEater93[br][br][size=1]Posted on: April 15, 2009, 10:44:32 pm[/size][hr]So I have to break up the string into characters then test those individual characters to see if they are digits, keep the digits, then put that into an int?

item.dc:creator: @PeeHPee PeeHPee
item.description:
@PeeHPee wrote:

do what unlimited orb said first, rewriting something when there is already a convenience method for it is dumb (in this case, checking if the character is smaller than 48, and bigger than 58).

see Character.isNumber()

item.source: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @Fireeater93 Fireeater93
item.description:
@Fireeater93 wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:28, topic:273738”]@Fireeater93, I’m assuming you don’t fully understand how the try&catch block works. So I’ll explain it to you:

The method [tt]parseInt(java.lang.String)[/tt] in the Integer class attempts to parse an integer value from the String provided. Now, you see, occasionally the input provided will not follow the expectations of a standard integer. Additional characters (i.e. ‘a’, ‘b’, ‘%’, "^’) will be thrown in rendering the integer invalid. When this occurs, an exception is thrown by the name of [tt]java.lang.NumberFormatException[/tt]; I’m sure the name is self-explanatory. Using the aforementioned process, one is able to identify the occasional invalid integer and return some sort of response if wanted.[/quote]

Ahhh, thank you. I was wondering if there was any use for exceptions. I can’t wait to try this in my program. Maybe I’ll post it when I’m done.

Read full topic

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:29, topic:273738”]This is ridiculous. The original question was whether or not there was a way to filter an alphanumeric String for its numerical elements. I answered that question. That should have been the end of this thread.

Instead, frank_ decides to answer by posting his opinion of what the program should do. That was his first mistake: projecting his beliefs upon the OP. Somehow, the age-old practice of defensive programming was morphed into “frank_'s method” in this thread. How this happened, I do not know. What I do know is that “frank_'s method” was the first thing that crossed my mind, but did I respond with it? No! And here’s why…

A question stated this specifically should be answered just as specifically. Perhaps he was making a guessing game for victims of Parkinson’s Disease. Designing the program to accept arbitrary input, and then filtering it after the fact, would prevent them from having to repeatedly retype their number.

If frank_ truly cared about the OP’s question, instead of trying to provoke chaos, he would have asked him to elaborate on the purpose of the question and gone from there. I never once said that “frank_'s method” was wrong.

Where frank_ really screwed up was taking my comment on arguing for compile time efficiency seriously. Of course the difference in compile time would be unnoticeable! He doesn’t even acknowledge this fact, though, because he doesn’t understand what a compiler does. Instead, he decides to think of runtime efficiency in place of compile time efficiency. At any rate, I made it clear that I slipped up when I used integers instead of characters to represent ‘0’ and ‘9’. I wasn’t arguing for compile time efficiency; I just mentioned that, if I wanted to, I could. It’s not like every book on programming ever doesn’t berate the use of hardcoded numbers! In retrospect, I found it funny that I even took the time out to reference an ASCII chart. Mistakes happen.

Answering the OP’s question does not mean that I agree with what he’s doing! How this train of thought popped up in this thread is beyond me. There is no “unlimitedorb’s method” and there is no “frank_'s method”. There’s absolutely nothing here that hasn’t been done before.[/quote]
sry but this is a forum, not wikianswers
theres nothing saying one cant make a suggestion, and if frank hadn’t made that suggestion OP would still be using that silly method instead of what he really wanted.

Read full topic

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

This is ridiculous. The original question was whether or not there was a way to filter an alphanumeric String for its numerical elements. I answered that question. That should have been the end of this thread.

Instead, frank_ decides to answer by posting his opinion of what the program should do. That was his first mistake: projecting his beliefs upon the OP. Somehow, the age-old practice of defensive programming was morphed into “frank_'s method” in this thread. How this happened, I do not know. What I do know is that “frank_'s method” was the first thing that crossed my mind, but did I respond with it? No! And here’s why…

A question stated this specifically should be answered just as specifically. Perhaps he was making a guessing game for victims of Parkinson’s Disease. Designing the program to accept arbitrary input, and then filtering it after the fact, would prevent them from having to repeatedly retype their number.

If frank_ truly cared about the OP’s question, instead of trying to provoke chaos, he would have asked him to elaborate on the purpose of the question and gone from there. I never once said that “frank_'s method” was wrong.

Where frank_ really screwed up was taking my comment on arguing for compile time efficiency seriously. Of course the difference in compile time would be unnoticeable! He doesn’t even acknowledge this fact, though, because he doesn’t understand what a compiler does. Instead, he decides to think of runtime efficiency in place of compile time efficiency. At any rate, I made it clear that I slipped up when I used integers instead of characters to represent ‘0’ and ‘9’. I wasn’t arguing for compile time efficiency; I just mentioned that, if I wanted to, I could. It’s not like every book on programming ever doesn’t berate the use of hardcoded numbers! In retrospect, I found it funny that I even took the time out to reference an ASCII chart. Mistakes happen.

Answering the OP’s question does not mean that I agree with what he’s doing! How this train of thought popped up in this thread is beyond me. There is no “unlimitedorb’s method” and there is no “frank_'s method”. There’s absolutely nothing here that hasn’t been done before.

Read full topic
item.source: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

@Fireeater93, I’m assuming you don’t fully understand how the try&catch block works. So I’ll explain it to you:

The method [tt]parseInt(java.lang.String)[/tt] in the Integer class attempts to parse an integer value from the String provided. Now, you see, occasionally the input provided will not follow the expectations of a standard integer. Additional characters (i.e. ‘a’, ‘b’, ‘%’, "^’) will be thrown in rendering the integer invalid. When this occurs, an exception is thrown by the name of [tt]java.lang.NumberFormatException[/tt]; I’m sure the name is self-explanatory. Using the aforementioned process, one is able to identify the occasional invalid integer and return some sort of response if wanted.

Read full topic
item.source: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @Fireeater93 Fireeater93
item.description:
@Fireeater93 wrote:

bowserjr2:

You should disallow writing letters, if they write something that is not a number or not in the range of the right ask for a new input and tell them whats wrong.

Yeah but with the little knowledge I have of Java, I wouldn’t know how to prevent them from typing in anything that’s not a number. Also, if I did do that I would have to check that it only contains 0-9 but it does not neccessarily have to contain all of them.

[quote=“frank_, post:3, topic:273738”]how about making that 48 and 57 ‘0’ and ‘9’ respectively, so you know what the hell they are meant to represent

i would be more inclined to do something along the lines of

// prompt int guess = 0; boolean valid = false; try { guess = Integer.parseInt(input); valid = true; } catch (NumberFormatException e) valid = false; } if (!valid) { // maybe inform incorrent } else { // check answer }[/quote]

Thank you! That’s perfect! I had heard about the try and catch methods but I wasn’t really sure how to implement them. I’ll try this and see how it works.

Read full topic
item.source: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:24, topic:273738”]You should disallow writing letters, if they write something that is not a number or not in the range of the right ask for a new input and tell them whats wrong.[/quote]That’s exactly what frank_ was attempting to get at.

[quote=“la­wl, post:25, topic:273738”]as for using ‘0’ instead of 47… etc, i cant stand when people use integer values in place of characters, it makes it so much harder to read the code and is an awful practice. id much rather have cleaner code than 0.000000001 longer compile time[/quote]I couldn’t agree more. For example: a table used for some sort of hashing algorithm (or anything else that floats your boat) consisting of only the values of each character used would not only look ugly, but it would not be understandable to the average person - that is, unless you’re some freak who decided memorizing the values would be a fun thing to do.

Read full topic

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

though i am biased to disagree with frank i actually agree with him this time, you (unlimitedorb) are making silly arguments and he is right to suggest to simply only accept numeric values and retry when its invalid because that makes much more sense than removing the invalid characters imo

as for using ‘0’ instead of 47… etc, i cant stand when people use integer values in place of characters, it makes it so much harder to read the code and is an awful practice. id much rather have cleaner code than 0.000000001 longer compile time

item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:20, topic:273738”]I would argue the method frank_ posted is alot easier.[/quote]It’s not what the OP was looking for (see unlimitedorb’s response); however, frank_'s method makes much more sense as stripping the ‘number’ of non-digits would be stupid. The person inputting information shouldn’t be inputting non-digits anyway.

An alternative would involve the Character class and the [tt]isNumber[/tt] and/or [tt]isLetter[/tt] methods.

item.title: Convert String (with chars and numbers) into int?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

LOL!

Okay the compiler has to do a little extra work. I haven’t looked at javac closely enough but I would assume that the ’ mark is one token. The character another and the ’ mark yet another. Meanwhile a series of numbers would be interpreted as a single token (an integer).

I’m not sure about you but TWO! (only possibly) extra tokens would cost you… NOTHING!

As previously covered the runtime performance is the same.

So we sacrifice readability for… 0.00001ns of compile time performance?

Read full topic
